summary.text_en: Aristotle established systematic natural philosophy! He researched biology, physics, logic, ethics - almost all fields. Though some views later overturned, he pioneered observational and classificatory methods for studying nature.
key_points_en: Proposed four elements theory and motion theory

story.text_en: In 343 BC, Aristotle became tutor to 13-year-old Alexander (later Alexander the Great). He founded Lyceum in Athens, teaching while walking, called 'Peripatetic School'. He collected numerous animal and plant specimens, wrote over 150 works covering almost all fields of human knowledge.

fun_facts.text_en: He entered Plato's Academy at 17, stayed 20 years until teacher's death.
He dissected over 50 animals, first discovered octopus mating with tentacles, confirmed 2000 years later!
Medieval Europe called him 'The Philosopher', no name needed, like calling God.

experiment.title_en: Observational Experiment: Animal Dissection and Classification
experiment.description_en: Aristotle dissected over 50 organisms including fish, birds, mammals, recording internal structures in detail. He discovered sharks are viviparous, heart forms first in chicken egg incubation. Based on blood, respiration, reproduction characteristics, he classified over 500 animals, establishing first systematic biological classification.
experiment.why_en: Through observation and comparison, finding common features and differences in organisms - fundamental method of scientific classification.

simple_explanation.text_en: Aristotle like super curious child, wanting to know 'why' about everything in world. He caught various animals to study, classifying them systematically. He thought stones fall because 'earth' wants to return to ground, flames rise because 'fire' wants to return to sky. Though these ideas later proven wrong, he taught people to carefully observe, classify, and think.

impact.text_en: Aristotle one of Western science founders. His thought dominated Europe nearly 2000 years until challenged in Renaissance. Though his physics overturned by Newton, his biological observations, logic system, ethical thought still valuable today. His greatest contribution was establishing systematic methods for studying nature.

influenced_by.contribution_en: Theory of Forms and philosophical speculation methods

influenced.contribution_en: Inherited biological classification and observation methods

influence_chain.legacy_text_en: Aristotle studied under Plato but opposed teacher's Theory of Forms, emphasizing observation of actual world. His four elements and geocentrism developed by Ptolemy into complete system, dominating Middle Ages. During Renaissance, Galileo experimentally overturned his motion theory. But his biological observation methods inherited by Darwin, logic still philosophical foundation today.

quiz.question_en: What four elements did Aristotle believe all matter was composed of?
quiz.explanation_en: Aristotle proposed four elements theory: earth, water, air, fire compose all matter. Each element has natural place, earth heaviest at bottom, fire lightest at top. This theory dominated Western science nearly 2000 years until birth of modern chemistry.
